title: 106_hr2436
content: The Act titled "Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999" amends Title 18, United States Code to include a new chapter for the protection of unborn children. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 adds a new chapter to Title 18, United States Code, titled "Protection of unborn children." It states that anyone who causes the death or bodily injury to a child in utero through violating certain laws is guilty of a separate offense, with punishment similar to that for the mother. Proof of knowledge of the victim's pregnancy or intent to harm the unborn child is not required. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 establishes penalties for causing bodily harm or death to an unborn child. The act specifies that intentional killing of the unborn child will be punished under existing laws for killing a human being, without the possibility of the death penalty. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 lists various sections of different acts that are relevant to its provisions. It clarifies that prosecution is not allowed for conduct related to abortion with proper consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child, or any actions by a woman towards her unborn child. The term 'unborn child' is defined within the act. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 1999 defines 'unborn child' as a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb.
